keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested in October 2025 on a charge of threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously convicted of obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct in a restricted area during the Capitol riot and sentenced to nearly two years in prison.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier in 2025 as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants, drawing criticism from lawmakers and public figures.
Moynihan allegedly sent a text message stating he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and claimed Jeffries must be eliminated, indicating a clear threat of violence.
The New York State Police reported concerns about Moynihan's recent drug abuse and increased homicidal ideations, suggesting potential mental health and substance use issues.
A New York judge ordered Moynihan to remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on whether he can be released pending trial for making a terroristic threat.
Moynihan’s prior attorneys cited opioid addiction and political engagement during the Trump presidency as background factors in his actions and legal history.

Law enforcement is particularly concerned about threats against public figures in the wake of recent high-profile assassinations, such as Charlie Kirk, highlighting broader national security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man convicted of participating in the January 6 Capitol attack, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested in October 2025 on a charge of threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan was arrested after allegedly stating in a text message that he would kill Jeffries 'for the future' and that he must be eliminated. The threat comes amid heightened concern over political violence following the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk. Moynihan, who previously struggled with opioid addiction and political engagement during the Trump presidency, is currently in prison awaiting a hearing on whether he can be released pending trial on terroristic threat charges. Law enforcement has raised alarms about his recent drug use and homicidal ideations, and the case underscores broader national concerns about threats against public officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
